BY CAROLYN SCHURR
The Johns Hopkins Institutions rival a number of Baltimore's major businesses in employment and total business
expenditures, according to a
study of the economic impact of
the Johns Hopkins Institutions
on the city of Baltimore in
1980. The study, prepared by
M. Ramona Montoya and Dr.
Katharine C. Lyall of the Johns
Hopkins Graduate Program in
Public Policy and the Center for
and
Planning
Metropolitan
Research, was commissioned by
the University's Office of Community Affairs. It updates a
similar report that was issued in
1973.
The purpose of the report is

to reveal to the local community
the ways in which one of its
major "not-for-profit" institutions contributes to the economic base. It will also reveal to the
University the nature and magnitude of its own activities that
affect the community in direct
and measurable ways. It is not
the primary purpose of institutions such as Johns Hopkins to
create jobs, generate business, or
boost sales of durable goods
in Baltimore; rather, the major
contributions of the Hopkins
Institutions are their social,
intellectual, and cultural resources. However, the study
does focus on the quantifiable
impacts of Hopkins-related activities on three sectors of local
economy: business, city govern-

In an effort to arrest the "condo craze" which has permeated much of the Baltimore area, including the Homewood
community,a Senate subcommittee has pressed for the passage of
emergency legislation that would tighten the restrictions on
condominium conversion.
The law, if passed, would require apartment owners to set
aside 20 percent of their rental units for senior citizens and
handicapped tenants for three years, pay up to $700 in moving
expenses for other tenants, and give current tenants the first
opportunity to buy the new converted units.
Among the other bills that have been introduced during
this session is a proposal to make peppermint lemonade the
official state drink, a bill to allow 18 ounce yogurt containers to
be sold in Maryland and a bill which according to a brief capsule
summary in yesterday's Baltimore Sun would "allow use of

The study reveals that $326
million in expenditures were
directly or indirectly attributable to the Hopkins Institutions
in Baltimore in 1980, an increase
of 66 percent over the 1973
total. Included in these institutions are the Johns Hopkins
University (Homewood Campus:
Faculty of Arts and Sciences,
Faculty of Engineering; East
Baltimore Campus: School of
Hygiene and Public Health,
School of Medicine), Johns
Hopkins Hospital, the Peabody
Conservatory of Music, and the
Broadway Management Corporation. These institutions are a
major industry in the city's
economic base.
In 1980, the Hopkins Institutions produced more than
24,359 jobs in Baltimore. These
jobs generated more than $160
million in personal income and
nearly $5 million in purchases of
durable goods in 1980. These
figures rank Hopkins as a major
employer in the Baltimore City
and metropolitan area. In fact,
the Hopkins Institutions employ
more people than do the city's
two largest department stores, or
three largest newspapers, or all
its commercial banks. Hopkins
Institutions were among the
fastest-growing employers in the
city, increasing employment
from 8,000 to nearly 12,000
between 1973 and 1980.
Though the Johns Hopkins
University and Hospital are
tax-exempt, they are responsible
both directly and indirectly for

sizable cash payments to the
city. In 1980, Baltimore city
received $11,372,733 in cash
revenues from real estate taxes,
nonreal property tax, state education aid, inspection fees,
water, parking tax, and other
areas.
The substantial growth in
visitors to the University and
Hospital has also had an impact
on Baltimore's economy. In
1973, 11,000 visitor days were
attributed to Hopkins-related
staff and activities, while in
1980, the figure rose to 50,000.
Approximately $7 million in
associated expenditures can be
traced to the activities of visitors
to Hopkins. The largest increase
in visitors has occured in out-ofstate participants who attend
continuing education seminars at
the Medical Institutions. Full
time undergraduate and graduate
students at Hopkins spent more
than $14 million last year on
goods and services in Baltimore.
The total number of students at
the Hopkins Institutions in 1980
was 4,739, up only slightly over
1973.
A larger number of
students in 1980 were renting
housing in Baltimore city. The
median payment by students
renting housing was $160 per
month excluding utilities, more
than twice the 1973 amount.
The median monthly expenditures of Hopkins students was
reported to be $121 per month,
including food, books, transportation, and entertainment.
Since 1976, the Johns
Hopkins University and Hospital

have constructed nine major
buildings in Baltimore city, at an
average cost of more than $10
million each. In addition, $3
million per year has been spent
to repair and refurbish existing
buildings.
Construction has
begun for the Space Telescope
Science Institute building, budgeted at $8.9 million. The third
phase of the Biology Complex is
also scheduled for this year, at
$8 million. These two projects
will generate an additional 773
full-time construction jobs and
155 apprenticeships in 1982.
On the cost side, the city
provided services in 1980 for
faculty, staff, and students of
the Hopkins Institutions valued
at more than $30 million. $2.1
million went toward the cost of
public education for the children
of Hopkins faculty, staff, and
students.
In general, the study estimates, Institutions-related activities in 1980 generated $243
million of additional business
volume in the city; accounted
for about $78 million of business real property, equipment,
and inventories; and generated
about $75 million in additional
bank credit in the city. "These
figures place the Hopkins Institutions among some of the city's
most substantial businesses in
terms of their contribution to
private sector economic activity
in the city," state the authors.

2. An Incriminating Silence
A small smorgasbord of items for
praise and complaint this week. First the
praise:
Congratulations to Larry Lappin and
the Student Council for their apparent
success in bringing the Ramones, the
popular punk group, to Hopkins. While
these pioneers of the current forms of
"angry young men" music are not necessarily to everyone's .taste, their "star"
magnitude should ensure th4it the event is a
financial success. Hopkins has a reputation
as a rotten concert school, and the Ramones concert should prove that such a
reputation is undeserved and unnecessary.
Failure in the past has been a result of a
kind of vicious cycle of negative thinking
amoung Hopkins concert planners: unwilling to spend big bucks on big names for
fear of insufficient audience turnout, they
went for second-rank performers and got
the small turnout they were afraid of, thus
confirming their own opinion. (Witness
last year's Carolyn Mas and Jorma Kaukonen fiascos.)
One note of warning: if the $1000
plus the SC has reportedly spent on improving the sound system in Shriver Hall is
insufficient, then the Council should do
everything short of building a new concert
hall next door to ensure that things sound
okay. The sound in Shriver has been
atrocious in the past; last year, it made
Kaukonen's delicate acoustic first set
coarse and cloudy, and his hard rock
second set absolutely unbearable.

As a college senior in fairly stable mental
health, I feel qualified to share survival tips compiled
over my four years of higher education. These tips
were produced through much` anguish, through the
pressured epoch of exams, the panic of approaching
and passing deadlines, and the realization that leaving
school on a Thursday night to take advantage of
Amtrak's excursion fare is more important than
missing a few classes or even quizzes.
Perhaps the most important fact to remember
in understanding this guide is that, while each student
is unique, everybody goes through cycles of doubt and
depression. This guide does not attempt to change the
student's natural constitution, but helps to recognize
the symptoms of typical mental oscillation and offers
constructive ways to treat these symptoms.
I have organized this self-help guide into three
Depression, Loneliness, and Boredom.
divisions:

Depression
Depression is quite common among students.
What causes depression: Schoolwork is one of the
major causes, as are a recent failure, a physical defect,
and television watching. Some television watchers find
the news conducive to depression, but I find The Love
Boat invariably depressing. Symptoms of depression
include listlessness, increased or extremely decreased
appetite, sadness, insatiable desire to sleep, avoidance
of one's friends, and the playing of certain "sad" songs.
In a recent survey at a Hopkins party, favorite songs to
accompany depression included pieces by Keith
Jarrett, Judy Collins, and Pink Floyd, and Hank
Williams'"I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry."
Most people don't realize the enormous energy
involved in thorough depression. For people interested
in serious depression, three degrees of intensity may be
found. Mild depression is constant in some individuals,
and manifests itself in continual low-key sadness and
the use of sarcasm (see "Silent Sarcastic Retort"),
which is an effective social defense. Moderate depression requires isolation, self-pity, consumption of
"mother foods"(See "Mother Foods"), disorientation,
and psychological scabbiness. Total depression is a
true art, and, when executed by professionals, saps all
personal energy, cuts off outside help, and creates what
I like to call The Basket-Case Senior.
Often, friends try to "cheer up" the victim of
depression, but I maintain that this is not the answer.

"Don't ever let anyone cheer you up," I recommend to
my acquaintances. My method of dealing with this
mental debilitation is called:

Creative
Depression
Creative depression strives to channel negative,
self-defeating energy into productive behavior. The
idea is not to divert one's attention from the problem,
but to come into contact with one's own "dark side"
while engaging in some form of positive physical
activity. Cleaning the apartment or house is one
excellent example of Creative Depression, as are
greasing hinges, fumigating, changing car oil, painting,
bathing pets, and plunging toilets. Part of the therapeutic value of this activity is in realizing that even in
depression, the student can function in "normal"
society. This builds confidence.
Physically unmotivated students may prefer
intellectual modes of enjoying Creative Depression.
Memorizing has been found to be a valid form of
expressing and enjoying depression to its fullest. Try
memorizing poetry. One of my favorite depression
memorization exercises is the last part of "Casey at
the Bat":
The sneer is gone from Casey's lips, his teeth
are clenched in hate.
He pounds with cruel vengeance his bat upon
the plate;
And now the pitcher holds the ball, and now he
lets it go,
And now the air is shattered by the force of
Casey's blow.
Oh, somewhere in this favored land the sun is
shining bright,
The band is playing somewhere,and somewhere
hearts are light;
And somewhere men are laughing, and somewhere children shout,
But there is no joy in Mudville—Mighty Casey
has struck out!
Depression time is also a good time to note
song lyrics Which have never before been clear. Slow
down and stop the needle. One student discovered the
Bee Gee's hit was really called "More Than a Woman"
and not "Four-Legged Woman."

Loneliness
Depression is not the only symptom of unstable
mental health. Loneliness is an unavoidable condition
which many people mistake for depression. Ways to
recognize real loneliness include listening to the radio
and television at the same time, talking aloud to
oneszlf, paranoia, and invisibility. Severely lonely
people think they are shrinking or expanding freakishly.
What can ease loneliness? First, learn to think
of it in a positive light. There is a Spanish refrain
which says, "Mas vale andar solo clue mal
acompanado," which means,"It is better to walk alone
than to be badly accompanied." In other words, it's
better to spend time alone than with someone who
cheapens one's existence. Quality loneliness focuses on
time spent alone. It ceases to look at time as a segment
of misery, a countdown to solitude. Every second of
Quality Loneliness is a challenge to see how well the
student can tolerate living with him or herself. Time
loses its sequential arrangement and becomes a Picasso
collection of fragmented moments. The mind is expected to wander, to move ahead and backward, to enjoy
not having to share, act, or compromise because of
human social obligation.
I have compiled a short list of Quality Loneliness situations which may serve as guidelines for the
student testing his or her ability to deal with loneliness:
It is better to spend a Thursday night writing
letters on C-Level than to go to the Rat.
It is better to watch reruns of Three's Company
and Barney Miller than to see Weekend WonderFlix'
Casablanca for the sixth time. Many college students
think it is their moral obligation to see Casablancaand
other old films, so that they can say, "I saw that old
film in college." This is a fallacy.

It's better to shoot baskets alone than to be
peer-pressured into a game of BIA basketball because
some team is short one player.
It is better to cross St. Paul Street and walk
alone than to meet an acquaintance who talks GPA and
is a nose-picker besides.
It is better to do laundry alone than to compromise one's solitude by attending a class dance in the
Glass Pavilion which features flat beer and old faces.

Boredom
Finally, in this brief sketch of mental health
problems and treatments for students, boredom must
be examined. Boredom is among the commonest of
health nuisances, and is to be blamed for both obnoxious and listless behavior.
What are signs of boredom'? Nail biting, procrastination, listlessness, repetition, depression and
loneliness are unmistakable signs of boredom. If you
learn to recognize these symptoms, sanity is possible.
Fortunately, boredom is easy to cure. Just as in
depression and loneliness, creativity plays an important
part in dealing with boredom. The following is a list of
deterrents for boredom.
Put on make-up. Take it off.
Rearrange your room. Dangle pencils in your nostrils.
Take the No. 3 bus to Towson and back
Go downtown and ride the glass elevators in the
Hyatt Regency
Climb to the roof of McCoy and hang out
there.
Skip pebbles in the President's Pond.
Write amusing letters to the editor of the
News-Letter
Design a septic tank
Buy M&Ms and segregate them. Eat them color
by color.
'Watch T.V. at the Grad Club.
Go to WaWa—they scoop potato salad as well as
they cut cold meat.
Bother friends who are trying to study in the
library.
other the bureaucrats in your favorite University
office. I like the Placement Office the best.

Diet and exercise are essential. An old refrain
says, "Bowels that move make a sane thinker." One
trick for foolproof regularity is called "The Human
Enema." In this diet, you may eat as many meals as
you like, but dessert should be a bowl of bran cereal.
Drink lots of water. Explosive results, and plenty of
guaranteed sane thinking.
Everyone knows how hard it is to make time to
go to the gym. The squash courts are often full, and in
the pool the lanes are usually crowded. Many people
fall into a dangerous rut called Recreation for Minimal
Enjoyment.
There are forms of enjoyable and convenient
exercise that are out of the mainstream. Sweating, for
example, may not be aerobic dancing, but is a valid
form of sedentary activity. Dress warmly and go watch
a swim meet in the gym. Do not shed garments.
Afterwards, go outside and roll in the snow. Another
exercise idea is bowling. Believe it or not, there is a
bowling alley in the gym, although the pins don't reset
automatically. Ask at the cage. The library is yet
another source of exercise. Pretend the elevator is
booby-trapped and you can only use the stairs. Pretend the same person who booby-trapped the elevator
is chasing you through book stacks.
University housing is a perfect opportunity for
students to form health clubs. A Wolman Hall Club
might partake in the following workout: start in the
basement with a stretching session; do three wind
sprints up and down the hall;jog from the basement to
the sixth floor; run across the sixth floor to the opposite side of the building; jog down to the fifth floor;
zig-zag down to the basement again. Repeat twice.
If University Housing health clubs don't appeal,
join ROTC. Running in army boots appears to be a
vigorous way to train, and it can never hurt to know
how to scale a barbed wire fence.

As a college senior in fairly stable mental
health, I feel qualified to share survival tips compiled
over my four years of higher education. These tips
were produced through much` anguish, through the
pressured epoch of exams, the panic of approaching
and passing deadlines, and the realization that leaving
school on a Thursday night to take advantage of
Amtrak's excursion fare is more important than
missing a few classes or even quizzes.
Perhaps the most important fact to remember
in understanding this guide is that, while each student
is unique, everybody goes through cycles of doubt and
depression. This guide does not attempt to change the
student's natural constitution, but helps to recognize
the symptoms of typical mental oscillation and offers
constructive ways to treat these symptoms.
I have organized this self-help guide into three
Depression, Loneliness, and Boredom.
divisions:

Depression
Depression is quite common among students.
What causes depression: Schoolwork is one of the
major causes, as are a recent failure, a physical defect,
and television watching. Some television watchers find
the news conducive to depression, but I find The Love
Boat invariably depressing. Symptoms of depression
include listlessness, increased or extremely decreased
appetite, sadness, insatiable desire to sleep, avoidance
of one's friends, and the playing of certain "sad" songs.
In a recent survey at a Hopkins party, favorite songs to
accompany depression included pieces by Keith
Jarrett, Judy Collins, and Pink Floyd, and Hank
Williams'"I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry."
Most people don't realize the enormous energy
involved in thorough depression. For people interested
in serious depression, three degrees of intensity may be
found. Mild depression is constant in some individuals,
and manifests itself in continual low-key sadness and
the use of sarcasm (see "Silent Sarcastic Retort"),
which is an effective social defense. Moderate depression requires isolation, self-pity, consumption of
"mother foods"(See "Mother Foods"), disorientation,
and psychological scabbiness. Total depression is a
true art, and, when executed by professionals, saps all
personal energy, cuts off outside help, and creates what
I like to call The Basket-Case Senior.
Often, friends try to "cheer up" the victim of
depression, but I maintain that this is not the answer.

"Don't ever let anyone cheer you up," I recommend to
my acquaintances. My method of dealing with this
mental debilitation is called:

Creative
Depression
Creative depression strives to channel negative,
self-defeating energy into productive behavior. The
idea is not to divert one's attention from the problem,
but to come into contact with one's own "dark side"
while engaging in some form of positive physical
activity. Cleaning the apartment or house is one
excellent example of Creative Depression, as are
greasing hinges, fumigating, changing car oil, painting,
bathing pets, and plunging toilets. Part of the therapeutic value of this activity is in realizing that even in
depression, the student can function in "normal"
society. This builds confidence.
Physically unmotivated students may prefer
intellectual modes of enjoying Creative Depression.
Memorizing has been found to be a valid form of
expressing and enjoying depression to its fullest. Try
memorizing poetry. One of my favorite depression
memorization exercises is the last part of "Casey at
the Bat":
The sneer is gone from Casey's lips, his teeth
are clenched in hate.
He pounds with cruel vengeance his bat upon
the plate;
And now the pitcher holds the ball, and now he
lets it go,
And now the air is shattered by the force of
Casey's blow.
Oh, somewhere in this favored land the sun is
shining bright,
The band is playing somewhere,and somewhere
hearts are light;
And somewhere men are laughing, and somewhere children shout,
But there is no joy in Mudville—Mighty Casey
has struck out!
Depression time is also a good time to note
song lyrics Which have never before been clear. Slow
down and stop the needle. One student discovered the
Bee Gee's hit was really called "More Than a Woman"
and not "Four-Legged Woman."

also fits under the category of Necessary Repression.
The SSR is not the most recommendable way of
handling depression, but can be useful in extreme cases
when it is important to act out hostilities while remaining socially acceptable. For example, human stupidity
is very obvious to people suffering from depression.
Rather than offend an innocent observer, a silent,
sarcastic retort brings a touch of humor to the situation, while keeping the depressed person as inoffensive

Loneliness
Depression is not the only symptom of unstable
mental health. Loneliness is an unavoidable condition
which many people mistake for depression. Ways to
recognize real loneliness include listening to the radio
and television at the same time, talking aloud to
oneszlf, paranoia, and invisibility. Severely lonely
people think they are shrinking or expanding freakishly.
What can ease loneliness? First, learn to think
of it in a positive light. There is a Spanish refrain
which says, "Mas vale andar solo clue mal
acompanado," which means,"It is better to walk alone
than to be badly accompanied." In other words, it's
better to spend time alone than with someone who
cheapens one's existence. Quality loneliness focuses on
time spent alone. It ceases to look at time as a segment
of misery, a countdown to solitude. Every second of
Quality Loneliness is a challenge to see how well the
student can tolerate living with him or herself. Time
loses its sequential arrangement and becomes a Picasso
collection of fragmented moments. The mind is expected to wander, to move ahead and backward, to enjoy
not having to share, act, or compromise because of
human social obligation.
I have compiled a short list of Quality Loneliness situations which may serve as guidelines for the
student testing his or her ability to deal with loneliness:
It is better to spend a Thursday night writing
letters on C-Level than to go to the Rat.
It is better to watch reruns of Three's Company
and Barney Miller than to see Weekend WonderFlix'
Casablanca for the sixth time. Many college students
think it is their moral obligation to see Casablancaand
other old films, so that they can say, "I saw that old
film in college." This is a fallacy.

It's better to shoot baskets alone than to be
peer-pressured into a game of BIA basketball because
some team is short one player.
It is better to cross St. Paul Street and walk
alone than to meet an acquaintance who talks GPA and
is a nose-picker besides.
It is better to do laundry alone than to compromise one's solitude by attending a class dance in the
Glass Pavilion which features flat beer and old faces.

Boredom
Finally, in this brief sketch of mental health
problems and treatments for students, boredom must
be examined. Boredom is among the commonest of
health nuisances, and is to be blamed for both obnoxious and listless behavior.
What are signs of boredom'? Nail biting, procrastination, listlessness, repetition, depression and
loneliness are unmistakable signs of boredom. If you
learn to recognize these symptoms, sanity is possible.
Fortunately, boredom is easy to cure. Just as in
depression and loneliness, creativity plays an important
part in dealing with boredom. The following is a list of
deterrents for boredom.
Put on make-up. Take it off.
Rearrange your room. Dangle pencils in your nostrils.
Take the No. 3 bus to Towson and back
Go downtown and ride the glass elevators in the
Hyatt Regency
Climb to the roof of McCoy and hang out
there.
Skip pebbles in the President's Pond.
Write amusing letters to the editor of the
News-Letter
Design a septic tank
Buy M&Ms and segregate them. Eat them color
by color.
'Watch T.V. at the Grad Club.
Go to WaWa—they scoop potato salad as well as
they cut cold meat.
Bother friends who are trying to study in the
library.
other the bureaucrats in your favorite University
office. I like the Placement Office the best.

Diet and exercise are essential. An old refrain
says, "Bowels that move make a sane thinker." One
trick for foolproof regularity is called "The Human
Enema." In this diet, you may eat as many meals as
you like, but dessert should be a bowl of bran cereal.
Drink lots of water. Explosive results, and plenty of
guaranteed sane thinking.
Everyone knows how hard it is to make time to
go to the gym. The squash courts are often full, and in
the pool the lanes are usually crowded. Many people
fall into a dangerous rut called Recreation for Minimal
Enjoyment.
There are forms of enjoyable and convenient
exercise that are out of the mainstream. Sweating, for
example, may not be aerobic dancing, but is a valid
form of sedentary activity. Dress warmly and go watch
a swim meet in the gym. Do not shed garments.
Afterwards, go outside and roll in the snow. Another
exercise idea is bowling. Believe it or not, there is a
bowling alley in the gym, although the pins don't reset
automatically. Ask at the cage. The library is yet
another source of exercise. Pretend the elevator is
booby-trapped and you can only use the stairs. Pretend the same person who booby-trapped the elevator
is chasing you through book stacks.
University housing is a perfect opportunity for
students to form health clubs. A Wolman Hall Club
might partake in the following workout: start in the
basement with a stretching session; do three wind
sprints up and down the hall;jog from the basement to
the sixth floor; run across the sixth floor to the opposite side of the building; jog down to the fifth floor;
zig-zag down to the basement again. Repeat twice.
If University Housing health clubs don't appeal,
join ROTC. Running in army boots appears to be a
vigorous way to train, and it can never hurt to know
how to scale a barbed wire fence.
